title: 106_s2599
content: The Act titled "Immigration and Naturalization Service Data Management Improvement Act of 2000" amends Section 110 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to establish an Integrated Entry and Exit Data System. The Attorney General is required to implement an integrated entry and exit data system, defined as an electronic system that provides access to alien arrival and departure data in an electronic format from the Department of Justice or State. It produces reports of arriving and departing aliens by nationality and immigrant status. The integrated entry and exit data system collects information on nationality, immigrant status, arrival, and departure dates of aliens in the United States. It matches arrival and departure data, identifies nonimmigrants overstaying their authorized period, and assists the Attorney General in making required reports. No additional authority is granted to impose documentary or data requirements. No new documentary or data collection requirements can be imposed by the Attorney General or the Secretary of State under this section, including requirements waived for certain aliens or inconsistent with the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Attorney General and Secretary of State's authority is not reduced by this section. By December 31, 2003, an integrated entry and exit data system must be implemented for airports and seaports, ensuring data can be accessed by immigration officers at different locations. The Attorney General must implement an integrated entry and exit data system by December 31, 2004, for high-traffic land border ports of entry. This system will include alien arrival and departure data and be accessible by immigration officers at airports, seaports, and land border ports of entry. The Attorney General must fully implement the integrated entry and exit data system by December 31, 2005, for all ports of entry into the United States. Annual reports analyzing the data from the system must be submitted to the Committees on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Attorney General must implement the integrated entry and exit data system by December 31, 2005, for all US ports of entry. Annual reports analyzing departure data by nationality and classification of aliens must be submitted to Congress. The Attorney General must implement an integrated entry and exit data system by December 31, 2005, for all US ports of entry. Departure data is obtained through the system or other means at the end of an alien's authorized stay, with details by nationality and date of arrival in the US. The number of nonimmigrants overstaying their authorized period is also reported by nationality. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State, determines who can access the system. The Attorney General can input and access data in the integrated entry and exit data system. Other law enforcement officials may also be granted access for law enforcement purposes. The system will be continuously updated using task force recommendations, with appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2008. The table of contents of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended to update the item relating to section 110 for fiscal years 2001 through 2008. "Sec. 110. Integrated entry and exit data system." - SEC. 3. TASK FORCE. Establishment of a task force, chaired by the Attorney General and composed of 16 members, to carry out duties related to the integrated entry and exit data system. Members appointed by the Attorney General will include representatives from various government agencies. The Task Force, chaired by the Attorney General, consists of 16 members from government agencies and private sector representatives. Members are appointed for the life of the Task Force and serve without compensation. Vacancies are filled by the Attorney General. The Task Force, chaired by the Attorney General, consists of 16 members from government agencies and private sector representatives who serve without compensation. Members who are officers or employees of the United States also serve without additional compensation. They are allowed travel expenses while away from their homes or regular places of business. The Task Force's duties include evaluating how the Attorney General can efficiently carry out section 110 of the Illegal Immigration. The Task Force, chaired by the Attorney General, evaluates how to effectively implement section 110 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. This includes improving traffic flow at airports, seaports, and land border ports of entry through data collection, data sharing, technology utilization, cooperation between sectors, and collaboration among Federal and State agencies. The Task Force, chaired by the Attorney General, evaluates implementing section 110 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. This involves improving traffic flow at airports, seaports, and land border ports of entry by enhancing information technology systems and considering different data systems, infrastructure, and processing procedures. The Task Force also determines the cost of implementing recommendations and the appointment of an executive director and necessary personnel without regard to civil service laws. The executive director of the Task Force will be compensated at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Other personnel's compensation can be set by the Attorney General without following certain pay rate regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement with agency head approval. The Attorney General can procure temporary services for the Task Force at specified rates. The Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services upon request. The Task Force may conduct hearings and sessions as needed. The Task Force can hold hearings, gather official data from US departments, and submit annual reports to Congress with findings and recommendations. The Task Force is responsible for measuring progress, evaluating remaining work, estimating completion time, and costs. The Attorney General may delegate report preparation to the Commissioner. Legislative recommendations are made to implement Task Force recommendations and secure funding authorization. The Task Force, under the Attorney General's authority, is responsible for evaluating progress, estimating costs, and making legislative recommendations for funding authorization. The Attorney General may delegate report preparation to the Commissioner. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2003 to carry out the Task Force's work. The Congress believes that the Attorney General should work with other government officials to enhance international border management cooperation with affected foreign countries.
